patterns.pattern: First-time contributors with maintainer label have significantly higher merge likelihood regardless of missing metadata
XS and S size labels correlate with ~26-28% merge rates, providing 2-4% boost over baseline and compensating for weak author history
Authors with 0% merge rate across 5+ prior PRs (low-merge authors) face deterministic rejection despite compensatory signals like size labels or fix classification
Fix-type changes boost merge likelihood by 10-20% over baseline, particularly when focused on single components
High-priority categories (agents, commands, gateway) provide 15-25% baseline uplift over general categories
Maintainer labels override weak author credentials and missing metadata with ~90% merge rate signal
Documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30%) that XS size labels can offset
Authors with >40% prior merge rate or experienced-contributor labels are strong merge candidates independent of size/scope
Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, tests, CI status) increases uncertainty but can be compensated by strong author history or explicit size labels
Narrow, single-component scope provides 5-10% merge boost for first-time contributors with no other signals
Multi-channel or multi-component touches from unknown authors signal scope creep and depress merge likelihood
Feature additions from first-time contributors require compensatory signals (maintainer label, XS size, high-priority category) or face below-baseline merge likelihood
L size labels provide no merge boost and may indicate scope risk requiring established author trust
Authors with baseline-to-above merge rates (20-50%) paired with category uplift and size S/XS labels achieve 50%+ merge likelihood
Security-adjacent or critical-path infrastructure fixes from underperforming authors (12% merge rate) still face below-baseline merge likelihood
100% author merge rate history (even with single prior PR) signals strong credibility and >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope
Non-draft status is baseline expectation; draft status is primary negative signal but not decisive alone
